Award.AwardTitle: CCSS: Spectral Filter Array For Multispectral Imaging

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective:
The objective of this project is to enable a new paradigm of spectral filter array (SFA) based image sensors in the visible wavelength range. This multispectral imaging problem is formulated as the task of
making finite spatial-spectral measurements on a hyperspectral image signal with minimal risks for aliasing. The proposed SFA design exploits the periodic response of multilayer dielectric interference
filters that has a natural interpretation in the Fourier sampling theories, giving direct correspondences between the refractive index contrasts, layer thicknesses and the fidelity of the captured spectral
image.

Intellectual merit:
The intellectual merit is the understanding of how the spectral filters in image sensors affect the spatial spectral fidelity of the multispectral images acquired by SFA based sensors. The proposed joint
processing-hardware solution is capable of capturing considerably sharper image than other SFA-based sensors considered to date, since extra spectral samples are measured with minimal sacrifices to spatial
resolution. The expected outcomes of the research include multilayer thin film filters with optimal spectral response, a high fidelity SFA sensor, and an advanced post-capture processing algorithm.

Broader impacts:
The broader impact is the development of SFA based multispectral sensor for applications that require portable or simple, inexpensive solutions. The fidelity of spectral images directly affects food and
water safety, remote sensing, geology, surveillance, biomedical imaging, environment monitoring, forensics, and mineralogy. The proposed educational and outreach program leverages various outlets to
target local industries, a large graduate population comprised of practitioners of sensor exploitation, and tutorial sessions at high impact conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Key advantage of multispectral imaging (MSI) is the ability to make inference on the identity or the state of the objects based on their spectral characteristics—spectroscopy enables chemical and material identification, provides minimally-invasive alternative to biopsy, automates geophysical surveying, and boosts the accuracy of object recognition tasks. These discriminating features are not available to conventional color image sensors that only capture metameric color information (i.e. RGB). However, MSI systems are considerably more complex than color image sensors since many narrowband filters are needed to isolate the intensities at various wavelengths of light.

We designed a single-shot MSI sensor designed to analyze the spectral characteristics of an object at each pixel. We significantly reduced the number of required filters by developing an alternative to the narrowband filter-based multispectral modality. Specifically, dielectric interference filters have spectrally broadband and periodic transmittance responses in the wavenumber domain, which has a natural correspondence to the Fourier sampling theory. We demonstrated in hardware that interference filters avoid aliasing that contaminates the spectra when undersampling with conventional narrowband filters. Because of this, there are a number of advantages to multichroic filters with different sinusoidal transmission responses, including a better spectrum recovery from discrete filters and the preservation of spectral features such as peaks and absorption bands that are critical for target detection. Due to its foundation in Fourier transform spectroscopy, we refer to the proposed multichroic filter-based image acquisition technique as Fourier MSI. 

The single-shot image acquisition is achieved by appealing to the successes of the color filter array (CFA) in conventional cameras. We developed a spectral filter array (SFA), a set of N predetermined spectral filters spatially multiplexed over an array of pixel sensors. Thanks to Fourier MSI framework, far fewer number of spectral filters are needed to recover spectral features, preserving high spatial resolution as a result. A post-capture interpolation step (called demosaicking) is then used to recover the full multispectral image from the subsampled sensor data. We designed and fabricated an array of pixel-level spectral filter array using the same cavity material (ZnS). We then bonded the fabricated spectral filter array to the detector surface. We demonstrated a single-shot and a video frame rate imaging capabilities for the Fourier multispectral imaging sensor in the visible and near-infrared ranges, and confirmed that the advantages of the Fourier multispectral imaging are indeed maintained by the spectral filter array configuration.

This work practicalizes SFA based multispectral sensor. Though the usages of multispectral imaging are wide spread, the impact will be greatest for multispectral imaging applications that require portable, general purpose, or simple inexpensive solutions. The fidelity of spectral images directly affects the capabilities of food and water safety, remote sensing, geology, surveillance, biomedical imaging, environment monitoring, forensics, and mineralogy.
